title: AIS - Automatic Intercept System
historical_context: This article discusses the DAIS II system, a significant technology in telecommunications during the early 1980s, focusing on how calls to non-working numbers are handled by telephone companies.
target_audience: Telecommunications professionals, hackers interested in telephony, security researchers.
short_summary: The article provides an in-depth look at the DAIS II system, which automates the process of intercepting calls to non-working numbers. It explains the technical workings of the system, including the roles of various components and how calls are processed.
summary:
In this article, Taran King delves into the workings of the DAIS II (Distributed Automatic Intercept System), a crucial component in telecommunications that automates the announcement of non-working numbers. The system operates by routing calls through a Class 5 End Office, utilizing Automatic Number Identification (ANI) to retrieve information from an intercept database. The article outlines the processes involved in both ANI and Operator Number Identification (ONI) calls, detailing how automated announcements are generated and the role of operators when the system encounters issues. It emphasizes the efficiency of DAIS II in managing call traffic and providing accurate information to callers, showcasing the technology's significance in the telecommunications landscape of the time.

King also provides a comprehensive overview of the system's architecture, including the various components such as the Audio Response System (ARS), Automatic Call Distributor (ACD), and the intricacies of the Trunk Time Switch (TTS). He explains how these components interact to ensure seamless communication and efficient handling of calls, even in cases where operator intervention is necessary. The article serves as both a technical guide and a historical document, reflecting the state of telecommunication technology in the early 1980s and its implications for future developments in automated systems.
